title: Which team will win the 2021 NBA Championship?
possible_answers: There will not be a 2021 NBA Championship
preds:
Dang. Not looking good for CP3…
If Suns stay alive it’ll be a tossup. Otherwise Bucks are back to life.

The Suns have their backs against the wall and need to win Game 6 in Milwaukee and game 7 at home to win the championship. Milwaukee will by winning either Game 6 or Game 7. The two teams have been seemingly evenly matched throughout the series, but with Milwaukee up 3-2 (and being winners of 3 straight) I'm giving them a slight edge (55%-45%) in win probability for each of the remaining games' baseline estimate. Game 6: Bucks home court advantage, but Suns have their backs against the wall, so I'm adjusting the percentage slightly up for the Bucks (57%-43%).
Game 7: Suns home court advantage, and this will only occur given the Suns win game 6, so I'm adjusting this games win percentage estimate to 50-50. This yields (rounding to nearest percent):
Suns chance to win: .43 × .5 = .22
Bucks chance to win: .78
Phoenix Suns, a very compact team, very balanced, has shown steady game

The Phoenix Suns will win the 2021 NBA Championship. While they finished the regular season with a better record than their Finals opponent (the Milwaukee Bucks), advanced stats portray the Suns and Bucks as similarly strong teams. In the postseason thus far, the Suns have a slightly better net rating, but postseason stats have a smaller sample-size and are largely matchup-based. The two regular season games in which the teams matched up were determined by 1-point margins, so the results of those games are inconclusive. I believe the Suns will win however, because of their dominance throughout this postseason relative to the Bucks. The Suns comfortably defeated both the Lakers and Nuggets, and struggled slightly against the Clippers, while the Bucks only comfortably swept the Heat, having major issues against the Nets and Hawks. The Bucks have various exploitable weaknesses, including Giannis Antetokounmpo's current injury and inability to shoot the ball well, Mike Budenholzer controversial coaching decisions and lack of adjustments, and the Bucks' overreliance on 3-point shooting. The Suns have the ability to score more efficiently at the rim, in the midrange, from the free-throw line, and only slightly less efficient from beyond the arc. The Bucks have no answer for Deandre Ayton, who is having the most efficient scoring postseason of all time, and can conversely defend Giannis better than any other defender in the league (per NBA.com). Chris Paul, Devin Booker, Mikal Bridges, Jae Crowder, Cameron Payne, Cameron Johnson, and Torrey Craig can provide efficient offense and lockdown defense for Phoenix, whereas Milwaukee lacks the depth to square off with them. Jrue Holiday and Khris Middleton can provide star support for Giannis, P.J. Tucker can provide good defense and corner shooting, and Bobby Portis Jr. can have his way against the Suns bench lineup, but they simply aren't equipped to deal with the resilient Suns team. Additionally, Monty Williams was a frontrunner for Coach of the Year this season, and has made quality adjustments in every series, and his superior coaching along with Chris Paul's superior leadership will let this Suns team win the series in 5 or 6 games.

Although the crowd isn't necessarily wrong, it's early to be this confident. 
Pump the brakes people.

It looks like Phoenix Suns rule the entire Western conference and has what it takes to win the 2021 NBA championship. They neutralize Nikola Jokić perfectly, and will dominate probably Utah in the conference finals. Whoever wins the Eastern Conference, will find it hard to compete, allthemore all other pairs seem to need a full-stretch best-of-seven series to determine who will advance to the conference finals. 
LA Clippers: low to no chances
Brooklyn Nets: very good season, very talented team, but a long season appears to take its toll (Harden) and they could lose focus.
Milwaukee Bucks: even though they're the underdogs, they have a chance to recover from an early 0-2 in this series against Nets, which would put the psychologic momentum in their favor. Most likely NBA finals pairs:
Philadelphia 76ers -  Phoenix Suns ("Another team")
Milwaukee Bucks  Phoenix Suns ("Bucks"/"Another team")
James Harden will be back and the team is packed with players with experience in the Finals

Nets have the highest likelihood to win the finals, even with Harden questionable. Brooklyn will win the eastern conference and may have a harder time with the western conference winner, is still favored to win. All sports books are also favoring Brooklyn.
Bucks looked very strong. Clippers & Lakers struggling.

Nets - Up 1-0 against BOS. Should win series
Clippers - Down 1-0 in series against DAL, but still favored to win series
Lakers - Down 1-0 to PHO, almost a pick em' on the road, but should win Game 3 at home. 
Bucks - Up 2-0 on MIA should win series "Another team" - PHI looks to be the best of the rest along with UTA. PHI should beat WAS handily in 4 or 5 games. UTA should beat MEM in the same 4 or 5 games. PHI may be the best team in this group (and isn't a base selection). No Championship - the days of cancelling everything for COVID are past. The games will be played and a champion will be crowned.

The no championship thing just isn't gonna happen. We're looking good on that front. Let's see how bad some of these injuries are...It's still tough to not take the field, though.

Read the first 1/3 of 538's explanation of RAPTOR vs ELO and I'm persuaded to just keep using the RAPTOR ratings here, since I don't really watch the NBA anymore! Maybe I'll start paying attention when the playoffs start.... https://fivethirtyeight.com/methodology/how-our-nba-predictions-work/
The healthy Lakers team will beat anyone, but the clippers and the Nets have an outside chance at the win with spoilers like the Jazz and Nuggets and 76ers always lurking.

Como no es nuevo, en la nba por lo general los campeones no varias mucho de año a año, a menos que el equipo campeón cambie drasticamente el plantel o el sistema de juego. El campeon actual de la NBA es Lakers, pero hay una gran diferencia entre los Lakers 2021 y los Lakers 2021, la ausencia de dos de sus mayores figuras, LeBron James y Anthony Davis. Si bien Lakers tiene mucho una banca que sin duda es capaz de suplir a James y Davis, equipos como Clippers y Nets han formado un gran equipo con super estrellas de la NBA que han sido campeones anteriomente, estos dos equipos han  tenido un gran desempeño a los largo de esta temporada y son potenciales campeones de la temporada 2021.

With this as a glimpse into the final seeding: https://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/31256635/nba-playoff-predictions-win-big-seeding-races
And of course: https://www.espn.com/nba/standings Will adjust periodically by seed.
A good, (outdated) reference: https://www.reddit.com/r/nba/comments/2ws9po/nba_finals_winners_by_seed/
Also outdated, but useful: https://www.businessinsider.com/nba-playoffs-are-predictable-2017-5 Need to review later: https://www.theringer.com/nba/2021/4/8/22373059/playoff-lottery-odds-probability-model

Update: Lakers made a strong move with Andre Drummond. Based on the health of LBJ and AD they are most likely to come out of the West. So likely Finals matchup will be Lakers versus nets. Only in the west there is more uncertainty if AD gets hurt. No challanger in the east during playoff time. Next update when KD, AD LBJ report back from injuries.
Small adjustments reflecting LeBron's injury and trade deadline moves.

Have to update this based on the Brooklyn Nets form and the new injury to Lebron. His injury seems like it will only keep him out for a couple weeks. However, this could result in a drastic slip for the Lakers in the standings making their playoff run much harder.

Forcast updated: Lebron & AD out, clearly diminishes the Lakers probability of winning it all.  No homecourt advantage, no well adjusted team, needing to chase for the playoffs etc. But the most important adjustments need to be made after trade deadline has passed and we see how the trades work out and after every playoff round. For the time being Lakers still in for the contention but not the favourite any longer. Plus Jazz and 76ers need to be accounted for as well.

https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2021-nba-predictions/?ex_cid=rrpromo
As a baseline, I will take the 538 RAPTOR scores and uncritically enter them in, as I have no opinion about this question currently. I'd like to see how the RAPTOR scoring methodology has performed in past years, particularly at equivalent points of the season. Generally speaking, the NBA is the most predictable of the major American sports leagues, with the best team winning the title more frequently. At the moment, however, there seems to be no clear favorite, with 6 teams given 12% or more odds, and a 7th team receiving 9%. The ELO forecast improves the odds for the Jazz, but I don't yet understand the two methodologies. Since the 538 page defaults to RAPTOR, I'm taking as a given they consider it a better system.

The Nets have been on a tear of late, even without KD. The team are too good on the offensive end and other teams just can't keep up on that end of the floor. However, there is an age old adage that defence wins championships and Brooklyn have a long way to go there. Lakers have played poorly without AD over the past 5 games. Again, I'm not writing them off with Lebron, but the emergence of Brooklyn and the OTHER team The Utah Jazz is scary. Utah are playing like the 2014 Spurs. Fluid offensive basketball with lockdown defence. The playoffs are where it will all matters in the end though and LeBron has the repertoire. I will continue to update this forecast as the season moves on. It has been a topsy turvy ride so far.
Updated version reflecting the fact that Anthony Davis is injured and might not get back in top shape and Nets seemed to have worked out their team chemistry. etc.

Still bullish on the nets. Beat phoenix without KD and Kyrie, Nash completely outcoached Monty Williams. Anthony Davis' achellies soreness is concerning, hopefully rest alleviates the pain but sometimes that can linger. Also think rondo was a better fit than Schroeder. And Howard was a better fit than Harrell. LeBron is having to carry them right now at 35 years of age which is always concerning. I know, I know, it's Ironman LeBron, but they got the least rest of any team in a short off season and now he is carrying a bigger load than he has in a long time early in the season. Enough factors to drop the Lakers 2% from previous forecast

Repeat championships are hard, ask any defending champion team in the NBA. However, LeBron James has been there and done it before. He's playing like an MVP once again and he's got a better supporting cast this year round. 
Injuries happen and Anthony Davis has picked up a recent calf strain that could create cause for concern, but we're a ways out from the playoffs. There are lots of other teams out there who are vying for the championship this year though. Philly and Utah are looking strong during the regular season, but neither of these squads have shown they have what it takes as players, or as established teams to win when the pressure is on in the playoffs. When picking "another team" you're also banking on the fact you have 26 other teams out of a pool of 30 (realistically there's only 6ish contenders). The Nets look frisky and are a wildcard here. Kevin Durant is one of few current players to beat LeBron in the finals over the past 5 years and he's looking like an MVP too. Unfortunately, the Nets team are not a well made team, and rookie coach Steve Nash may be in over his head come playoff time. Giannis is the reigning MVP too, and he looks like he's saving himself for the playoffs. I'd give him a slight nod here too. Finally, the Clippers while having a great team and arguably the second best player in the league (Kawhi) they also haven't shown they have the guts to beat the Lakers. However, I don't like betting against Kawhi given his record of success and I'd be likely to change my mind on this post All Star break.

A forecast of who wins the 2021 NBA championship would need to take into account a few factors:
- COVID-19 - the prevalence of and the level of vaccine uptake by stakeholders.
- Injuries - due to how NBA championship teams being structured with 'super stars' i.e. Lebron, KD, AD, Giannis, Kyrie, Harden, PG, Kwahi  there are very significant 'key person risks' that exist. So an injury to anyone of these players will significantly diminish the team's probabilities for winning the 2021 championship If AD and Lebron are healthy, it is most likely of the available choices that Lakers can repeat. Brooklyn, on paper, is the best team however 2 of the superstars have significant injury issues (KD and Kyrie). Harden although being an almost unstoppable offensive force, has not had any Finals experience. For the Clippers, PG is the X-factor. If he can perform like he has been in 2021 they have a at least a 25% chance of winning. Although, Giannis is showing improvement every year, he does not have a defensible track record in the playoffs.
It is is still possible for a dark horse candidate like Miami or Jazz to make and maybe win the Championship. Lastly, the NBA was somehow able to put together a 2020 season and crown a Champion. So it is fair to say that, it is a very low likelihood that there will not be a 2021 NBA Championship.

The pairing of two mvps and a third all star is extremely powerful. The nets regular season record will continue to be mediocre but their record against .500+ teams is 8-1. The coast but have another gear. Lakers have two MVP caliber players in lebron and AD as well. NBA is extremely dependent on star power. Ditto for Clippers, but Paul George has proven inconsistent. Bucks have a good roster offensively but don't think they can keep pace with brooklyn or Philly in a 7 game series. The 9% for other team is a mixture of Utah, Phoenix, and Philly.

I like what @Rad4Caster  did with his approach.  However, I think that due to COVID and potentially players missing playoff games with contract tracing, there is a little more uncertainty and variability, which favors underdogs.  Plus, Sportsbooks often take a VIG, so the implied percentages by the sportsbooks are a little inflated.  Lastly, I think that there has to be a >0% that the season gets canceled, which @Rad4Caster does, but some other people do not. Additionally, as a basketball fan my entire life, I also need to adjust the sportsbooks numbers slightly based on what i've seen.  I am lowering the Nets by a few % point because chemistry matter, and I think Kyrie is a cancer to that team.  Also, it often takes a super team 1 year to get acclimated with each other.

Lakers are fairly clear favorites at this point in the season, at least according to https://www.oddsshark.com/nba/championship-odds, which appears to do a decent job of compiling odds from a bunch of bookmakers (and if you really want good data on sports, use bookmakers, who stand to gain (or lose) boatloads of money if they're right (or wrong)). Repeats seem at first to be fairly uncommon in the NBA, but they've happened four times in the last 20 years, with one of those being a three-peat...so 5 out of 20 years we've had a repeat winner. 25% chances aren't bad. Oh, and one of those was the Heat, with Lebron on board. Next is Brooklyn, who have a dynamic trio of all-stars. I'm on board with giving them a high likelihood of being good, but I'm not sure all three will be able to share the limelight well. They bear more scrutiny as the season wears on, and especially in tight games, as it might be an indication of how they'll perform under pressure.  The Clippers and Bucks round out the top four, and #5 is pretty clearly far beyond those top four. So it looks like we have four leaders early in the season. There's something to be said for being able to bet on the field here, though. That's another 26 teams. You can't sleep on getting to put odds on another 26. The NBA always leans pretty heavily in favor of the frontrunners, and it's not THAT often that someone comes right out and surprises everyone, but it's 26 teams! And we're still early in the season! I'm giving that choice some love, especially because Golden State's included in that number. As for no championship, I'm giving that a fairly low probability here. Of course, COVID could be crazy, but the NBA and their bubble showed us that they were the class of the American pro sports leagues, and that was when we had no vaccine and were in the *height* of the pandemic. I'm willing to bet they'll make it happen again this year.

The Lakers and Nets should lead in each of their divisions and with the Clippers and Bucks being notorious for playing horrible in the playoffs it would almost be more likely that another team not mentioned like the Celtics or Nuggets win the finals.

Via negativa: going back to 1995 only three times the underdogs have won in the finals:  Pistons 2004, Mavericks 2011 and Toronto 2019, so one must take into account 25 : 3 = 12 % these outliers. Plus Tendency to form superteams in  the NBA got higher, so more bifurcated  title chances. Nevertheless one needs to assign at least 12 % chance to an underdog becoming champions. This year this tendeny is I believe twice as high, since the quality of excellent teams "who can get lucky on a championship run" is high with 6 teams, so twice the chance this season than in earlier decades.  Utah (strong start) Golden State, Dallas, Philly, Bucks and Boston each 4 %, since all of them can make the road to the finals. Brooklyn and Lakers are more or less a  coinflip at this time of evaluation 100 % - 24 % = 76 % among the high caliber teams.
 LAC half as likely to win versus LAL or Brooklyn therefore Brooklyn & Laker each 32 % and Clippers 12 %. 
Updates will be made with regard to the following upcoming facts. Injuries, Trades, Homecourt Advantage, not making the playoffs at the end of regular season, team chemistry, team mindset etc.
The Nets are too inconsistent of defence and have not got strength on the bench. Lakers look strong, would be able to beat any team comfortably in the playoffs. Longevity and talent.
The Lakers are still the team to beat, especially in a series as opposed to just one game.
